security_audit.summary: This is a documentation and guidance skill for building MCP servers. Contains helper Python scripts for connection management and evaluation. The scripts have standard network capabilities for API integration and can spawn subprocesses for local MCP server testing. All network endpoints are user-specified or well-known Anthropic API endpoints. No sensitive data collection or exfiltration patterns detected.

content.user_title: Build MCP servers for LLM integrations
content.value_statement: Creating MCP servers from scratch is complex without clear guidance. This skill provides a structured four-phase workflow for building production-ready MCP servers with proper tool design, input validation, and comprehensive testing. It includes reference implementations for Python and TypeScript, evaluation frameworks, and best practices for security and performance.
actual_capabilities: Guides MCP server creation through four phases: research, implementation, review, and evaluation
Provides Python FastMCP and TypeScript SDK implementation patterns with complete examples
Includes evaluation harness for testing MCP server effectiveness with QA pairs
Documents security best practices including OAuth, input validation, and data protection
Covers transport options (stdio, HTTP, SSE) and connection management patterns
limitations: Does not generate complete MCP server code automatically - provides patterns and guidance
Requires users to have API documentation for the service they want to integrate
Evaluation harness requires an Anthropic API key and valid evaluation XML files
Does not handle authentication with external services - users must implement their own auth

use_cases.title: Integrate external services
use_cases.description: Build MCP servers that expose external APIs as tools for LLMs, following best practices for naming, validation, and error handling.

use_cases.title: Test MCP server quality
use_cases.description: Create and run evaluation suites that test whether LLMs can effectively use your MCP server tools to complete real-world tasks.

use_cases.title: Design agent-friendly tools
use_cases.description: Design tools that optimize for limited context windows, provide actionable errors, and enable complete workflows rather than just API calls.

prompt_templates.title: Create MCP server
prompt_templates.prompt: Help me create an MCP server to integrate with the {service_name} API. I want to build tools for {specific_use_cases}. Follow the four-phase workflow in the mcp-builder skill.

prompt_templates.title: Add new tool
prompt_templates.prompt: Add a new tool called {tool_name} to my existing MCP server. It should {tool_description}. Use the patterns from the {language} implementation guide.

prompt_templates.title: Run evaluations
prompt_templates.prompt: Create an evaluation file for my {service_name} MCP server and run it using the evaluation harness. The evaluation should test read-only operations that require multiple tool calls.

prompt_templates.title: Review implementation
prompt_templates.prompt: Review my MCP server implementation against the quality checklist. Check that tools follow naming conventions, have proper input validation with {pydantic/zod}, and include comprehensive error handling.

output_examples.input: Help me create an MCP server for the GitHub API with tools for listing repositories and creating issues.
output: First, I need to gather information about the GitHub API:
1. Fetch the MCP protocol documentation from modelcontextprotocol.io
2. Load the Python SDK README from the modelcontextprotocol/python-sdk repository
3. Study the GitHub REST API documentation for endpoints needed
Based on the mcp-builder skill guidance, I'll design tools that:
- Consolidate related operations (e.g., check availability + create in one tool)
- Use human-readable identifiers over opaque IDs
- Provide concise and detailed response format options
Let me create a plan for the GitHub MCP server...

best_practices: Design tools for complete workflows, not just individual API endpoints. Consolidate related operations to reduce the number of tool calls needed.
Use input validation (Pydantic for Python, Zod for TypeScript) with clear constraints and descriptive error messages that guide LLMs toward correct usage.
Create evaluations with realistic, read-only questions that require multiple tool calls and verify answers through string comparison.
anti_patterns: Don't simply wrap every API endpoint as a separate tool. This creates tool sprawl and forces LLMs to make many calls for common tasks.
Avoid returning exhaustive data dumps. Implement character limits and truncation with guidance on how to filter or paginate results.
Do not skip evaluation. Without testing how LLMs actually use your tools, you cannot measure or improve the server quality.

faq.question: Which programming language should I use?
faq.answer: Python with FastMCP is recommended for beginners. TypeScript with MCP SDK offers more control and is better for complex projects with multiple transports.

faq.question: What are the character limits for responses?
faq.answer: The recommended limit is 25,000 characters. Implement truncation with clear messages that guide LLMs on how to filter or paginate to get more data.

faq.question: How do I connect MCP servers to Claude?
faq.answer: Use the MCP client to connect via stdio for local servers, or HTTP/SSE for remote servers. Configure transport settings in your Claude client configuration.

faq.question: Is my data safe when using MCP servers?
faq.answer: MCP servers only access data you explicitly configure. Follow security best practices: validate tokens, use HTTPS, and avoid collecting unnecessary data.

faq.question: Why are my evaluations failing?
faq.answer: Check tool descriptions are clear and comprehensive. Verify input parameters are well-documented. Ensure error messages are actionable and provide specific next steps.

faq.question: How does this compare to direct API calls?
faq.answer: MCP servers provide structured tool interfaces optimized for LLMs. They handle validation, formatting, pagination, and error handling, making API integration more reliable and consistent.
